V. IT was a trifling enough sign , but it had remained in [Susy]159-susy ’s mind : that first morning in [Venice]15-venice [Nick]170-nick had gone out without first coming in to see [her]159-susy . [She]159-susy had stayed in bed late , chatting with [Clarissa]187-clarissa , and expecting to see the door open and [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband appear ; and when [the child]547-the child left , and [she]159-susy had jumped up and looked into [[Nick]170-nick ’s room]548-nick ’s room , [she]159-susy found [it]548-nick ’s room empty , and a line on [his]170-nick dressing table informed [her]159-susy that [he]170-nick had gone out to send a telegram . It was lover - like , and even boyish , of [him]170-nick to think it necessary to explain [his]170-nick absence ; but why had [he]170-nick not simply come in and told [her]159-susy ! [She]159-susy instinctively connected the little fact with the shade of preoccupation [she]159-susy had noticed on [his]170-nick face the night before , when [she]159-susy had gone to [[his]170-nick room]549-his room and found [him]170-nick absorbed in letter ; and while [she]159-susy dressed [she]159-susy had continued to wonder what was in the letter , and whether the telegram [he]170-nick had hurried out to send was an answer to it . [She]159-susy had never found out . When [he]170-nick reappeared , handsome and happy as the morning , [he]170-nick proffered no explanation ; and it was part of [her]159-susy life - long policy not to put uncalled - for questions . It was not only that [her]159-susy jealous regard for [her]159-susy own freedom was matched by an equal respect for that of [others]397-others ; [she]159-susy had steered too long among the social reefs and shoals not to know how narrow is the passage that leads to peace of mind , and [she]159-susy was determined to keep [her]159-susy little craft in mid - channel . But the incident had lodged itself in [her]159-susy memory , acquiring a sort of symbolic significance , as of a turning - point in [her]159-susy relations with [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband . Not that these were less happy , but that [she]159-susy now beheld them , as [she]159-susy had always formerly beheld such joys , as [an unstable islet in a sea of storms]552-an unstable islet in a sea of storms . [Her]159-susy present bliss was as complete as ever , but it was ringed by the perpetual menace of all [she]159-susy knew [she]159-susy was hiding from [Nick]170-nick , and of all [she]159-susy suspected [him]170-nick of hiding from [her]159-susy .... [She]159-susy was thinking of these things one afternoon about three weeks after [their]553-their arrival in [Venice]15-venice . It was near sunset , and [she]159-susy sat alone on [the balcony]554-the balcony , watching the cross - lights on the water weave their pattern above the flushed reflection of [old palace - basements]555-old palace - basements . [She]159-susy was almost always alone at that hour . [Nick]170-nick had taken to writing in the afternoons -- [he]170-nick had been as good as [his]170-nick word , and so , apparently , had [the Muse]533-the muse and it was [his]170-nick habit to join [[his]170-nick wife]332-his wife only at sunset , for a late row on [the lagoon]527-the lagoon . [She]159-susy had taken [Clarissa]187-clarissa , as usual , to [the Giardino Pubblico]559-the giardino pubblico , where [that obliging child]560-that obliging child had politely but indifferently “ played”--Clarissa[159-susy] joined in the diversions of [her]560-that obliging child age as if conforming to an obsolete tradition -- and had brought [her]560-that obliging child back for a music lesson , echoes of which now drifted down from a distant window . [Susy]159-susy had come to be extremely thankful for [Clarissa]187-clarissa . But for [the little girl]540-the little girl , [her]159-susy pride in [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband ’s industry might have been tinged with a faint sense of being at times left out and forgotten ; and as [Nick]170-nick ’s industry was the completest justification for [their]563-their being where [they]563-their were , and for [her]159-susy having done what [she]159-susy had , [she]159-susy was grateful to [Clarissa]187-clarissa for helping [her]159-susy to feel less alone . [Clarissa]187-clarissa , indeed , represented the other half of [her]159-susy justification : it was as much on [the child]547-the child ’s account as on [Nick]170-nick ’s that [Susy]159-susy had held [her]159-susy tongue , remained in [Venice]15-venice , and slipped out once a week to post one of [Ellie]184-ellie ’s numbered letters . A day ’s experience of [the Palazzo Vanderlyn]189-the palazzo vanderlyn had convinced [Susy]159-susy of the impossibility of deserting [Clarissa]187-clarissa . Long experience had shown [her]159-susy that [the most crowded households]565-the most crowded households often contain [the loneliest nurseries]566-the loneliest nurseries , and that [the rich child]567-the rich child is exposed to evils unknown to less pampered infancy ; but hitherto such things had merely been to [her]159-susy one of the uglier bits in the big muddled pattern of life . Now [she]159-susy found [herself]159-susy feeling where before [she]159-susy had only judged : [her]159-susy precarious bliss came to [her]159-susy charged with a new weight of pity . [She]159-susy was thinking of these things , and of the approaching date of [Ellie Vanderlyn]184-ellie ’s return , and of the searching truths [she]159-susy was storing up for [that lady]568-that lady ’s private ear , when [she]159-susy noticed a gondola turning its prow toward the steps below [the balcony]554-the balcony . [She]159-susy leaned over , and [a tall gentleman in shabby clothes]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes , glancing up at [her]159-susy as [he]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes jumped out , waved [a mouldy Panama in joyful greeting]571-a mouldy panama in joyful greeting . “ [Streffy]164-streffy ! ”[159-susy] [she]159-susy exclaimed as joyfully ; and [she]159-susy was half - way down [the stairs]572-the stairs when [he]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes ran up [them]572-the stairs followed by [[his]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes luggage - laden boatman]573-his luggage - laden boatman . “ It ’s all right , [I]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes suppose?--Ellie said [I]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes might come , ”[570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes] [he]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes explained in a shrill cheerful voice ; “ and [I]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes ’m to have [[my]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes same green room]2268-my same green room with the parrot - panels , because [its]2268-my same green room furniture is already so frightfully stained with [my]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes hair - wash . ”[570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes] [Susy]159-susy was beaming on [him]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes with the deep sense of satisfaction which [his]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes presence always produced in [[his]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes friends]574-his friends . There was [no one]534-no one in [the world]2205-the world , [they]577-they all agreed , half as ugly and untidy and delightful as [Streffy]164-streffy ; [no one who combined such outspoken selfishness with such imperturbable good humour]578-no one who combined such outspoken selfishness with such imperturbable good humour ; [no one who knew so well how to make [you]580-you believe [he]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes was being charming to [you]580-you when it was [you]580-you who were being charming to [him]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes]579-no one who knew so well how to make you believe he was being charming to you when it was you who were being charming to him . In addition to these seductions , of which none estimated the value more accurately than [[their]581-their possessor]582-their possessor , [Strefford]267-strefford had for [Susy]159-susy another attraction of which [he]570-a tall gentleman in shabby clothes was probably unconscious . It was that of being the one rooted and stable being among the fluid and shifting figures that composed [[her]159-susy world]583-her world . [Susy]159-susy had always lived among [people so denationalized that those one took for Russians]584-people so denationalized that those one took for russians generally turned out to be American , and those one was inclined to ascribe to [New York]12-new york proved to have originated in [Rome]23-rome or [Bucharest]24-bucharest . [These cosmopolitan people , who , in countries not [their]585-these cosmopolitan people , who , in countries not their own own]585-these cosmopolitan people , who , in countries not their own , lived in [houses as big as hotels]586-houses as big as hotels , or in [hotels where [the guests]588-the guests were as international as [the waiters]589-the waiters]587-hotels where the guests were as international as the waiters , had inter - married , inter - loved and inter - divorced [each other]2188-each other over the whole face of [Europe]25-europe , and according to every code that attempts to regulate human ties . [Strefford]267-strefford , too , had [[his]267-strefford home in [this world]592-this world]591-his home in this world , but only one of [[his]267-strefford homes]593-his homes . The other , the one [he]267-strefford spoke of , and probably thought of , least often , was [a great dull English country - house in [a northern county]595-a northern county]594-a great dull english country - house in a northern county [, where a life as monotonous and self - contained as [his]267-strefford own]596-, where a life as monotonous and self - contained as his own was chequered and dispersed had gone on for generation after generation ; and it was the sense of [that house]597-that house , and of all it typified even to [his]267-strefford vagrancy and irreverence , which , coming out now and then in [his]267-strefford talk , or in [his]267-strefford attitude toward something or [somebody]598-somebody , gave [him]267-strefford a firmer outline and a steadier footing than [the other marionettes in the dance]599-the other marionettes in the dance . Superficially so like [them]600-them all , and so eager to outdo [them]600-them in detachment and adaptability , ridiculing the prejudices [he]267-strefford had shaken off , and [the people to whom [he]267-strefford belonged]601-the people to whom he belonged , [he]267-strefford still kept , under [his]267-strefford easy pliancy , the skeleton of old faiths and old fashions . “ [He]267-strefford talks every language as well as [the rest of [us]2270-us]2269-the rest of us , ”[159-susy] [Susy]159-susy had once said of [him]267-strefford , “ but at least [he]267-strefford talks one language better than the others ”[159-susy] ; and [Strefford]267-strefford , told of the remark , had laughed , called [her]159-susy [an idiot]602-an idiot , and been pleased . As [he]267-strefford shambled up [the stairs]572-the stairs with [her]159-susy , arm in arm , [she]159-susy was thinking of this quality with a new appreciation of its value . Even [she]159-susy and [Lansing]170-nick , in spite of [their]604-their unmixed Americanism , [their]604-their substantial background of [old - fashioned cousinships]605-old - fashioned cousinships in [New York]12-new york and [Philadelphia]26-philadelphia , were as mentally detached , as universally at [home]606-home , as touts at an International Exhibition . If [they]604-their were usually recognized as [Americans]190-americans it was only because [they]604-their spoke French so well , and because [Nick]170-nick was too fair to be “ foreign , ”[170-nick] and too sharp - featured to be English . But [Charlie Strefford]267-strefford was English with all the strength of an inveterate habit ; and something in [Susy]159-susy was slowly waking to a sense of the beauty of habit . Lounging on [the balcony]554-the balcony , whither [he]267-strefford had followed [her]159-susy without pausing to remove the stains of travel , [Strefford]267-strefford showed [himself]267-strefford immensely interested in the last chapter of [her]159-susy history , greatly pleased at its having been enacted under [his]267-strefford roof , and hugely and flippantly amused at the firmness with which [she]159-susy refused to let [him]267-strefford see [Nick]170-nick till [the latter]608-the latter ’s daily task was over . “ Writing ? Rot ! What ’s [he]170-nick writing ? [He]170-nick ’s breaking [you]159-susy in , [[my]159-susy dear]445-my dear ; that ’s what [he]170-nick ’s doing : establishing an alibi . What ’ll [you]159-susy bet [he]170-nick ’s just sitting there smoking and reading [Le Rire]191-le rire ? Let ’s go and see . ”[159-susy] But [Susy]159-susy was firm . “ [He]170-nick ’s read [me]159-susy [his]170-nick first chapter : it ’s wonderful . It ’s a philosophic romance -- rather like [Marius]192-marius , [you]159-susy know . ”[159-susy] “ Oh , yes -- [I]267-strefford do ! ”[267-strefford] said [Strefford]267-strefford , with a laugh that [she]159-susy thought idiotic . [She]159-susy flushed up like [a child]609-a child . “ [You]267-strefford ’re stupid , [Streffy]164-streffy . [You]267-strefford forget that [Nick]170-nick and [I]159-susy do n’t need alibis . [We]2272-we ’ve got rid of all that hyprocrisy by agreeing that [each]2273-each will give [the other]475-the other a hand up when either of [us]2272-we wants a change . [We]2272-we ’ve not married to spy and lie , and nag [each other]2188-each other ; [we]2272-we ’ve formed a partnership for [our]2272-we mutual advantage . ”[159-susy] “ [I]159-susy see ; that ’s capital . But how can [you]267-strefford be sure that , when [Nick]170-nick wants a change , [you]267-strefford ’ll consider it for [his]170-nick advantage to have one ? ”[159-susy] It was the point that had always secretly tormented [Susy]159-susy ; [she]159-susy often wondered if it equally tormented [Nick]170-nick . “ [I]159-susy hope [I]159-susy shall have enough common sense-- ”[159-susy] [she]159-susy began . “ Oh , of course : common sense is what [you]267-strefford ’re both bound to base [your]267-strefford argument on , whichever way [you]267-strefford argue . ”[159-susy] This flash of insight disconcerted [her]159-susy , and [she]159-susy said , a little irritably : “ What should [you]170-nick do then , if [you]170-nick married?--Hush , [Streffy]164-streffy ! [I]159-susy forbid [you]170-nick to shout like that -- [all the gondolas]2276-all the gondolas are stopping to look ! ”[159-susy] “ How can [I]170-nick help it ? ”[170-nick] [He]170-nick rocked backward and forward in [his]170-nick chair . “ ‘ If [you]170-nick marry , ’ [she]159-susy says : ‘ [Streffy]164-streffy , what have [you]170-nick decided to do if [you]170-nick suddenly become [a raving maniac]2277-a raving maniac ? ’ ”[170-nick] “ [I]159-susy said no such thing . If [[your]170-nick uncle]2278-your uncle and [[your]170-nick cousin]2279-your cousin died , [you]170-nick ’d marry to - morrow ; [you]170-nick know [you]170-nick would . ”[159-susy] “ Oh , now [you]170-nick ’re talking business . ”[170-nick] [He]170-nick folded [his]170-nick long arms and leaned over [the balcony]554-the balcony , looking down at the dusky ripples streaked with fire . “ In that case [I]170-nick should say : ‘ [Susan]159-susy , [[my]170-nick dear]445-my dear -- [Susan]159-susy -- now that by the merciful intervention of [Providence]193-providence [you]159-susy have become Countess of [Altringham]267-strefford in [the peerage of [Great Britain]28-great britain]2281-the peerage of great britain , and [Baroness Dunsterville]194-baroness dunsterville and d’Amblay in [the peerages of [Ireland]29-ireland and [Scotland]30-scotland]2282-the peerages of ireland and scotland , [I]170-nick ’ll thank [you]159-susy to remember that [you]159-susy are [a member of one of [the most ancient houses in [the United Kingdom]2285-the united kingdom]2284-the most ancient houses in the united kingdom]2283-a member of one of the most ancient houses in the united kingdom -- and not to get found out . ’ ”[170-nick] [Susy]159-susy laughed . “ [We]2286-we know what those warnings mean ! [I]611-i pity [[my]611-i namesake]2287-my namesake . ”[611-i] [He]611-i swung about and gave [her]159-susy a quick look out of [his]611-i small ugly twinkling eyes . “ Is there [any other woman in [the world]2205-the world]2288-any other woman in the world named [Susan]159-susy ? ”[611-i] “ [I]611-i hope so , if the name ’s an essential . [I]611-i ’ve seen it in practice too often . ”[611-i] “ Oh , well : as far as [I]611-i know , [everybody]2183-everybody ’s in perfect health at [Altringham]267-strefford . ”[611-i] [He]611-i fumbled in [his]611-i pocket and drew out a fountain pen , a handkerchief over which it had leaked , and a packet of dishevelled cigarettes . SUSY]159-susy found [Strefford]267-strefford , after [his]267-strefford first burst of nonsense , unusually kind and responsive . The interest [he]267-strefford showed in [her]614-i future and [Nick]170-nick ’s seemed to proceed not so much from [his]267-strefford habitual spirit of scientific curiosity as from simple friendliness . [He]267-strefford was privileged to see [Nick]170-nick ’s first chapter , of which [he]170-nick formed so favourable an impression that [he]170-nick spoke sternly to [Susy]159-susy on the importance of respecting [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband ’s working hours ; and [he]170-nick even carried [his]170-nick general benevolence to the length of showing a fatherly interest in [Clarissa Vanderlyn]187-clarissa . [Mrs. Vanderlyn]188-mrs. vanderlyn had said : “ Four weeks at the latest , ”[188-mrs. vanderlyn] and the four weeks were over , and [she]188-mrs. vanderlyn had neither arrived nor written to explain [her]188-mrs. vanderlyn non - appearance . [She]159-susy communicated [her]159-susy apprehensions to [Strefford]267-strefford . “ [I]159-susy do n’t trust [that green - eyed nurse]2310-that green - eyed nurse . [I]159-susy do n’t see why [Ellie]184-ellie has n’t come : [she]184-ellie was due last Monday . ”[159-susy] [[Her]159-susy companion]544-her companion laughed , and something in the sound of [his]544-her companion laugh suggested that [he]544-her companion probably knew as much of [Ellie]184-ellie ’s movements as [she]159-susy did , if not more . [She]159-susy would have given [the world]2205-the world , at that moment , to have been free to tell [Nick]200-nick what [she]159-susy had learned on the night of [their]626-their arrival , and then to have gone away with [him]200-nick , no matter where . But there was [Clarissa--]201-clarissa-- ! To fortify [herself]159-susy against the temptation , [she]159-susy resolutely fixed [her]159-susy thoughts on [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband . Of [Nick]200-nick ’s beatitude there could be no doubt . [He]200-nick adored [her]159-susy , [he]200-nick revelled in [Venice]15-venice , [he]200-nick rejoiced in [his]200-nick work ; and concerning the quality of that work [her]159-susy judgment was as confident as [her]159-susy heart . [She]159-susy still doubted if [he]200-nick would ever earn a living by what [he]200-nick wrote , but [she]159-susy no longer doubted that [he]200-nick would write something remarkable . The mere fact that [he]200-nick was engaged on a philosophic romance , and not a mere novel , seemed the proof of an intrinsic superiority . And if [she]159-susy had mistrusted [her]159-susy impartiality [Strefford]267-strefford ’s approval would have reassured [her]159-susy . Among [[their]628-their friends]629-their friends [Strefford]267-strefford passed as an authority on such matters : in summing [him]267-strefford up [his]267-strefford eulogists always added : “ And [you]159-susy know [he]267-strefford writes . ”[267-strefford] As a matter of fact , [the paying public]630-the paying public had remained cold to [his]200-nick few published pages ; but [he]200-nick lived among [the kind of people who confuse taste with talent , and are impressed by the most artless attempts at literary expression]631-the kind of people who confuse taste with talent , and are impressed by the most artless attempts at literary expression ; and though [he]200-nick affected to disdain [their]628-their judgment , and [his]200-nick own efforts , [Susy]159-susy knew [he]200-nick was not sorry to have it said of [him]200-nick : “ Oh , if only [Streffy]164-streffy had chosen-- ! ”[200-nick] [Strefford]267-strefford ’s approval of the philosophic romance convinced [her]159-susy that it had been worth while staying in [Venice]15-venice for [Nick]200-nick ’s sake ; and if only [Ellie]184-ellie would come back , and carry off [Clarissa]187-clarissa to [St. Moritz]32-st. moritz or [Deauville]33-deauville , the disagreeable episode on which [their]632-their happiness was based would vanish like a cloud , and leave [them]632-their to complete enjoyment . [Ellie]184-ellie did not come ; but [the Mortimer Hickses]177-the hickses did , and [Nick Lansing]170-nick was assailed by the scruples [[his]170-nick wife]332-his wife had foreseen . [Strefford]267-strefford , coming back one evening from [the Lido]34-the lido , reported having recognized the huge outline of [the Ibis]170-nick among [the pleasure craft of [the outer harbour]635-the outer harbour]634-the pleasure craft of the outer harbour ; and the very next evening , as [the guests of [Palazzo Vanderlyn]189-the palazzo vanderlyn]636-the guests of palazzo vanderlyn were sipping [their]636-the guests of palazzo vanderlyn ices at [[Florian]202-florian ’s]637-florian ’s , [the Hickses]177-the hickses loomed up across [the Piazza]638-the piazza . [Susy]159-susy pleaded in vain with [[her]159-susy husband]327-her husband in defence of [his]327-her husband privacy . “ Remember [you]327-her husband ’re here to write , [dearest]2233-dearest ; it ’s [your]327-her husband duty not to let [any one]2257-any one interfere with that .
